about.summary: The R package 'ashr' implements an Empirical Bayes approach for large-scale hypothesis testing and false discovery rate (FDR) estimation based on the methods proposed in M. Stephens, 2016, "False discovery rates: a new deal", <DOI:10.1093/biostatistics/kxw041>. These methods can be applied whenever two sets of summary statistics---estimated effects and standard errors---are available, just as 'qvalue' can be applied to previously computed p-values. Two main interfaces are provided: ash(), which is more user-friendly; and ash.workhorse(), which has more options and is geared toward advanced users. The ash() and ash.workhorse() also provides a flexible modeling interface that can accomodate a variety of likelihoods (e.g., normal, Poisson) and mixture priors (e.g., uniform, normal).

name: r-ashr
raw_recipe:
{% set version = "2.2-39" %}
{% set posix = 'm2-' if win else '' %}
{% set native = 'm2w64-' if win else '' %}

package:
  name: r-ashr
  version: {{ version|replace("-", "_") }}

source:
  url:
    - {{ cran_mirror }}/src/contrib/ashr_{{ version }}.tar.gz
    - {{ cran_mirror }}/src/contrib/Archive/ashr/ashr_{{ version }}.tar.gz
  sha256: 689591dcc55b589c90d01938c10a1e44e0a7dfd7f4f479dce2b31805c0631a9c

build:
  merge_build_host: True  # [win]
  number: 0
  rpaths:
    - lib/R/lib/
    - lib/

requirements:
  build:
    - {{ compiler('c') }}        # [not win]
    - {{ compiler('cxx') }}      # [not win]
    - {{ compiler('m2w64_c') }}        # [win]
    - {{ compiler('m2w64_cxx') }}        # [win]
    - {{posix}}filesystem        # [win]
    - {{posix}}make
    - {{posix}}sed               # [win]
    - {{posix}}coreutils         # [win]
    - {{posix}}zip               # [win]
  host:
    - r-base
    - r-matrix
    - r-rcpp >=0.10.5
    - r-squarem
    - r-assertthat
    - r-doparallel
    - r-etrunct
    - r-foreach
    - r-mixsqp
    - r-pscl
    - r-truncnorm
  run:
    - r-base
    - {{native}}gcc-libs         # [win]
    - r-matrix
    - r-rcpp >=0.10.5
    - r-squarem
    - r-assertthat
    - r-doparallel
    - r-etrunct
    - r-foreach
    - r-mixsqp
    - r-pscl
    - r-truncnorm

test:
  commands:
    - $R -e "library('ashr')"           # [not win]
    - "\"%R%\" -e \"library('ashr')\""  # [win]

about:
  home: https://github.com/stephens999/ashr
  license: GPL (>= 3)
  summary: 'The R package ''ashr'' implements an Empirical Bayes approach for large-scale hypothesis
    testing and false discovery rate (FDR) estimation based on the methods proposed
    in M. Stephens, 2016, "False discovery rates: a new deal", <DOI:10.1093/biostatistics/kxw041>.
    These methods can be applied whenever two sets of summary statistics---estimated
    effects and standard errors---are available, just as ''qvalue'' can be applied to
    previously computed p-values. Two main interfaces are provided: ash(), which is
    more user-friendly; and ash.workhorse(), which has more options and is geared toward
    advanced users. The ash() and ash.workhorse() also provides a flexible modeling
    interface that can accomodate a variety of likelihoods (e.g., normal, Poisson) and
    mixture priors (e.g., uniform, normal).'
  license_family: GPL3
  license_file: '{{ environ["PREFIX"] }}/lib/R/share/licenses/GPL-3'

extra:
  recipe-maintainers:
    - conda-forge/r

Stephens, 2016, "False discovery rates: a new deal", <DOI:10.1093/biostatistics/kxw041>. These methods can be applied whenever two sets of summary statistics---estimated effects and standard errors---are available, just as 'qvalue' can be applied to previously computed p-values. Two main interfaces are provided: ash(), which is more user-friendly; and ash.workhorse(), which has more options and is geared toward advanced users. The ash() and ash.workhorse() also provides a flexible modeling interface that can accomodate a variety of likelihoods (e.g., normal, Poisson) and mixture priors (e.g., uniform, normal).
# Depends: R (>= 3.1.0)
# Imports: Matrix, stats, graphics, assertthat, truncnorm, mixsqp, SQUAREM, doParallel, pscl, Rcpp (>= 0.10.5), foreach, etrunct
# LinkingTo: Rcpp
# Suggests: testthat, knitr, rmarkdown, ggplot2, REBayes

# NeedsCompilation: yes
# LazyData: true

# Repository: CRAN
# Date/Publication: 2019-02-22 09:50:03 UTC

about.summary: The R package 'ashr' implements an Empirical Bayes approach for large-scale hypothesis testing and false discovery rate (FDR) estimation based on the methods proposed in M. Stephens, 2016, "False discovery rates: a new deal", <DOI:10.1093/biostatistics/kxw041>. These methods can be applied whenever two sets of summary statistics---estimated effects and standard errors---are available, just as 'qvalue' can be applied to previously computed p-values. Two main interfaces are provided: ash(), which is more user-friendly; and ash.workhorse(), which has more options and is geared toward advanced users. The ash() and ash.workhorse() also provides a flexible modeling interface that can accomodate a variety of likelihoods (e.g., normal, Poisson) and mixture priors (e.g., uniform, normal).
